name: Hooked: The Molecular Basis of Addiction
base_name: Hooked: The Molecular Basis of Addiction

anti_reqs.name: Hooked: The Chemical Basis of Drug Addiction

long_desc: What makes us need something so much that it eclipses the most important aspects of our lives, such as family, friends, work, hobbies, health and wellness There are many different types of addiction this course will focus on molecular addictions, with an emphasis on those involving members of the opioid class of narcotics. The ongoing epidemic of opioid addiction, arising both from overprescription of pain killers and recreational use of heroin, has been widely reported and continues to rise at alarming rates, ravaging our urban and rural communities. In this course, we will explore the complicated role of chemistry in this epidemic, including the good elucidating mechanisms of action, developing clinically useful and safe opioids and nonopioids and the bad design and synthesis of increasingly addictive opioids. We will also discuss ethical questions faced by the pharmaceutical industry that develops, markets and sells these drugs, the medical community that prescribes them, the government agencies charged with regulating these activities and law enforcement agencies that attempt to stop the flow of drugs into and within the United States. The second half of the semester will focus on addiction to other drugs, including cocaine, marijuana, amphetamines, alcohol and nicotine. We will also discuss chemical approaches to treating addiction. Students who complete this course will emerge with a broad understanding and perspective on an issue that is of great scientific and societal importance.  The course will be organized in units that begin with a historicalsocietal big picture overview, followed by technical discussions of the underlying chemistry and biochemistry, concluding with consideration of the societal implications of addiction to each particular substance.

custom_fields.goals: Upon completion of this course, students shouldUnderstand the molecular basis of drug addiction including administration, biodistribution, receptor binding and alterations in brain function.Connect diverse societal factors that facilitated the spread of opioid addiction, including both illicit production, trafficking and distribution of recreational drugs as well as development, approval and marketing of prescription drugs.Compare historical progression of different drugs through society, including opiates, cocaine, amphetamines, nicotine and alcohol.Be aware of new treatments for addiction.
custom_fields.key_topics: The course provides a holistic view of addiction to opiates and other substances. Scientific topics will include medicinal chemistry, receptor biochemistry and pharmacology, while broader sociological, political and bureaucratic topics will include the role of ethics, regulation (FDA), law enforcement (DEA), Congressional oversight, health care, and journalism in creating, reporting and treating addiction. (The scientific topics in the course will be covered at a level that does not require prior coursework in chemistry or biology.)
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Students will be evaluated based on three types of assignments: (1) 3 homework assignments relating to the material covered in class, (2) A midterm take-home exam that will test the students' overall knowledge and (3) a capstone project in which the goal is to distribute $10,000,000,000 to address the opiate addiction epidemic. These assignments will each be worth 1/3 of the grade.
custom_fields.relevance: The explosion in substance use disorders, particularly involving opiates, is one of the defining social issues of our time, particularly here in the Ohio River valley. Understanding the chemistry and biochemistry of opiates and other addictive substances provides a scientific foundation for appreciating the molecular basis for these diseases, while discussing the broader societal forces that contribute to the societal and economic burdens will hopefully allow students to develop an informed, thoughtful and empathetic perspective on a problem that is impacting all facets of our community.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Instructor's notes, readings, podcasts and documentaries will provide source material for the lectures. The instructor will also hold two office hours per week and will be available by appointment. Students should also purchase three books: (1) Dreamland by Sam Quinones, (2) Never Enough by Dr. Judith Grisel, and (3) American Overdose by Chris McGreal.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Students can expect to spend 3-4 hours per week (outside of class) reading course materials and working on assignments. The workload will be fairly consistent, although the capstone project will begin approximately halfway through the semester and will require significantly more work than the other assignments (ca. 10-15 hours versus 2-3 hours).
